title: 1  Probability
text:
1.1 Random Variables
A random experiment is a procedure where uncertain events are observed. An outcome is the result of such an experiment, and the collection of all possible outcomes is called the sample space \(S\). For example:
Repetitions of a random experiment is known as a trial. If a coin is tossed twice \(S = \{(H, H), (T, H), (H, T), (T, T)\}\).
An event is a subset of the sample space.
The numerical results of an a random experiment are random variables(RV). For the example of a coin tossed twice, numeral values can be assigned to each outcome: \((H, H) = 0, (T, H) = 1, ...\)
The set of possible values for random variable \(X\) is denoted by \(Range(X)\), \(R_X\), \(\Omega\).

1  Probability
text:
a coin toss: \(S = \{heads,tails\}\)
roll a 6 sided die (D6): \(S = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}\)
number of rainy days in June: \(S = \{0, 1, ..., 30\}\)






I roll a D6 10 times. Let X be the number of 1’s observed. Then \(R_X = \{0, 1, ..., 10\}\)
How many attempts it takes for Manchester United (F.C.) defense to tighten up. Let Y represent the total number of games before they manage to keep a clean sheet. Then \(R_Y = \{ 1,2, ...\} = \mathbb{N}\) i.e. Y can be any positive integer.
The random variable T is the time (in hours) from now until the next earthquake occurs. This can be any non negative real number \(R_T = [0, \infty)\)

title: 1  Probability
text:
1.2 Discrete random variables
A random variable X is called discrete if:

\(\Omega\) is a finite set. E.g. \(\Omega_X = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}\).
a countably infinite set. E.g.:

Natural numbers \(\mathbb{N} = \{1, 2, 3, ...\}\),
Integers \(\mathbb{Z} = \{..., -1, 0, 1,...\}\),
Rational number, \(\mathbb{Q}\) (number that can be expressed as a fraction), etc..


If \(\Omega\) isn’t a countable set, X is continuous.

1.2.1 Definitions explained through an example
If a coin is tossed four times:

The sample space (S) —the list of all (\(2^4\)) possible outcomes— is \(S = \{(H, H, H, H), (H, H, H, T), ....\}\).
We define the RV, \(X\), as the number of heads that come up in the four coin tosses. Then the range of X is \(\Omega_X = \{x_1 = 0, x_2 = 1,..., x_5= 4\}\).
An event defined as the set of outcomes s in the sample space S. For example an event, A, could be “getting exactly 2 heads”. Then A would include all outcomes from the sample space where there are 2 heads, e.g.: \((HHTT), (HTHT),\) etc. In general terms \(A=\{s∈S|X(s)=x_k\}\)
Probabilities of events \(\{X=x_k\}\) are formally shown by the probability mass function (pmf) of \(X\), i.e. showing the probability of each value of \(\Omega_X\): \(P(X=0), ..., P(X=4)\). Formally, the pmf: \(f_X(x_k) = P(X=x_k)\).











To be a pmf, \(f_X\) must satisfy:

\(f_X \ge 0\) for \(x \in \Omega\). i.e \(P(X =x_k) < 0\)
\(\Sigma_{x \in \Omega} f_X = 1\)

From our example, for in each case \(f_X \ge 0\) and the sum is 1
